intro: Bystropogon smithii, commonly known as the Smith's mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of eucalyptus trees in southern Africa. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and has a distinctive appearance with small, leathery leaves and white, fleshy berries. The plant lacks true roots and absorbs water and nutrients through its haustoria, which attach to the host tree. It plays a role in local ecosystems by providing food for birds and insects. Bystropogon smithii is typically found in coastal and mountainous regions where its host trees thrive.
